The set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` can be written as the union of the sets of multiples `≤ N`
of primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

type:
∀ (N k : ℕ),
  N.roughNumbersUpTo k =
    (N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow).biUnion fun p => Finset.filter (fun m => m ≠ 0 ∧ p ∣ m) (Finset.range N.succ)
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_eq_biUnion
docString:
The set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` can be written as the union of the sets of multiples `≤ N`
of primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

The number of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` is bounded by the sum of the integer divisors of `N` in the interval `[k, N]`.

type: ∀ (N k : ℕ), (N.roughNumbersUpTo k).card ≤ (N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow).sum fun p => N / p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le
docString: The number of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` is bounded by the sum of the integer divisors of `N` in the interval `[k, N]`.

This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `N` and `k`, the set of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` can be expressed as a combination of sets. More specifically, the set is the union of sets of multiples less than or equal to `N` for each prime number `p` between `k` and `N`. In other words, for each of these primes `p`, it includes all the numbers in the set from `0` to `N` that are divisible by `p`, excluding zero.

type:
∀ (N k : ℕ),
  N.roughNumbersUpTo k =
    (N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow).biUnion fun p => Finset.filter (fun m => m ≠ 0 ∧ p ∣ m) (Finset.range N.succ)
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_eq_biUnion
docString: This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `N` and `k`, the set of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` can be expressed as a combination of sets. More specifically, the set is the union of sets of multiples less than or equal to `N` for each prime number `p` between `k` and `N`. In other words, for each of these primes `p`, it includes all the numbers in the set from `0` to `N` that are divisible by `p`, excluding zero.

`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

type: {R : Type u_1} → [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] → R → Prop
name: IsPrimePow
docString:
`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

An integer `n` is odd if and only if it is not even. Equivalently, `n` is odd if and only if it can be written in the form `2*k + 1` for some integer `k`, and it is even if and only if it can be written in the form `r + r` for some integer `r`.

type: ∀ {n : ℤ}, Odd n ↔ ¬Even n
name: Int.odd_iff_not_even
docString: An integer `n` is odd if and only if it is not even. Equivalently, `n` is odd if and only if it can be written in the form `2*k + 1` for some integer `k`, and it is even if and only if it can be written in the form `r + r` for some integer `r`.

This theorem states that for any natural numbers `N` and `k`, the cardinality (or size) of the set of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` is less than or equal to `N` times the sum of reciprocals of the primes between `k` and `N` inclusive. Here, a `k`-rough number is a number that has no prime divisors less than `k`.

type: ∀ (N k : ℕ), ↑(N.roughNumbersUpTo k).card ≤ ↑N * (N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow).sum fun p => 1 / ↑p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le'
docString: This theorem states that for any natural numbers `N` and `k`, the cardinality (or size) of the set of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` is less than or equal to `N` times the sum of reciprocals of the primes between `k` and `N` inclusive. Here, a `k`-rough number is a number that has no prime divisors less than `k`.

Equivalence between the set of natural numbers which are `≥ k` and `ℕ`, given by `n → n - k`.

type: (k : ℕ) → { n // n ∉ Multiset.range k } ≃ ℕ
name: notMemRangeEquiv
docString: Equivalence between the set of natural numbers which are `≥ k` and `ℕ`, given by `n → n - k`.

If `s` is an infinite set of natural numbers and `k > 0`, then `s` contains two elements `m < n`
that are equal mod `k`.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ}, s.Infinite → ∀ {k : ℕ}, 0 < k → ∃ m ∈ s, ∃ n ∈ s, m < n ∧ m ≡ n [MOD k]
name: Nat.exists_lt_modEq_of_infinite
docString:
If `s` is an infinite set of natural numbers and `k > 0`, then `s` contains two elements `m < n`
that are equal mod `k`.

There are exactly `⌊N/n⌋` positive multiples of `n` that are `≤ N`.
See `Nat.card_multiples` for a "shifted-by-one" version.

type: ∀ (N n : ℕ), (Finset.filter (fun k => k ≠ 0 ∧ n ∣ k) (Finset.range N.succ)).card = N / n
name: Nat.card_multiples'
docString:
There are exactly `⌊N/n⌋` positive multiples of `n` that are `≤ N`.
See `Nat.card_multiples` for a "shifted-by-one" version.

The positive non-`k`-smooth (so "`k`-rough") numbers up to and including `N` as a `Finset`

type: ℕ → ℕ → Finset ℕ
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo
docString: The positive non-`k`-smooth (so "`k`-rough") numbers up to and including `N` as a `Finset`

**Hermite Theorem**. Let `N` be an integer. There are only finitely many number fields
(in some fixed extension of `ℚ`) of discriminant bounded by `N`.

type: ∀ (A : Type u_2) [inst : Field A] [inst_1 : CharZero A] (N : ℕ), {K | |NumberField.discr ↥↑K| ≤ ↑N}.Finite
name: NumberField.finite_of_discr_bdd
docString:
**Hermite Theorem**. Let `N` be an integer. There are only finitely many number fields
(in some fixed extension of `ℚ`) of discriminant bounded by `N`.

The `k`-smooth numbers up to and including `N` as a `Finset`

type: ℕ → ℕ → Finset ℕ
name: Nat.smoothNumbersUpTo
docString: The `k`-smooth numbers up to and including `N` as a `Finset`

The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by `N` times the sum
of `1/p` over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

type: ∀ (N k : ℕ), ↑(N.roughNumbersUpTo k).card ≤ ↑N * ∑ p ∈ N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow, 1 / ↑p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le'
docString:
The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by `N` times the sum
of `1/p` over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by the sum of `⌊N/p⌋`
over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

type: ∀ (N k : ℕ), (N.roughNumbersUpTo k).card ≤ ∑ p ∈ N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow, N / p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le
docString:
The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by the sum of `⌊N/p⌋`
over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

If `n : ℕ+` is different from `1`, then it is the successor of some `k : ℕ+`.

name: PNat.exists_eq_succ_of_ne_one
docString: If `n : ℕ+` is different from `1`, then it is the successor of some `k : ℕ+`.

A subset of `ℕ` containing `k : ℕ` and closed under `Nat.succ` contains every `n ≥ k`.

type: ∀ {n k : ℕ} {S : Set ℕ}, k ∈ S → (∀ k ∈ S, k + 1 ∈ S) → k ≤ n → n ∈ S
name: Nat.set_induction_bounded
docString: A subset of `ℕ` containing `k : ℕ` and closed under `Nat.succ` contains every `n ≥ k`.

We define `m % k` in the same way as for `ℕ`
except that when `m = n * k` we take `m % k = k` This ensures that `m % k` is always positive.

name: PNat.mod
docString:
We define `m % k` in the same way as for `ℕ`
except that when `m = n * k` we take `m % k = k` This ensures that `m % k` is always positive.

If `n ≥ 2` equals zero in a separably closed field `k`, `b ≠ 0`,
then there exists `x` in `k` such that `a * x ^ n + b * x + c = 0`.

type:
∀ {k : Type u} [inst : Field k] [inst_1 : IsSepClosed k] {n : ℕ} (a b c : k),
  ↑n = 0 → 2 ≤ n → b ≠ 0 → ∃ x, a * x ^ n + b * x + c = 0
name: IsSepClosed.exists_root_C_mul_X_pow_add_C_mul_X_add_C
docString:
If `n ≥ 2` equals zero in a separably closed field `k`, `b ≠ 0`,
then there exists `x` in `k` such that `a * x ^ n + b * x + c = 0`.

If `|r| < 1`, then `n ^ k r ^ n` tends to zero for any natural `k`.

type: ∀ (k : ℕ) {r : ℝ}, |r| < 1 → Filter.Tendsto (fun n => ↑n ^ k * r ^ n) Filter.atTop (nhds 0)
name: tendsto_pow_const_mul_const_pow_of_abs_lt_one
docString: If `|r| < 1`, then `n ^ k r ^ n` tends to zero for any natural `k`.

**Kummer's Theorem**
Taking (`p - 1`) times the `p`-adic valuation of the binomial `n` over `k` equals the sum of the
digits of `k` plus the sum of the digits of `n - k` minus the sum of digits of `n`, all base `p`.

type:
∀ {p k n : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  k ≤ n → (p - 1) * padicValNat p (n.choose k) = (p.digits k).sum + (p.digits (n - k)).sum - (p.digits n).sum
name: sub_one_mul_padicValNat_choose_eq_sub_sum_digits
docString:
**Kummer's Theorem**
Taking (`p - 1`) times the `p`-adic valuation of the binomial `n` over `k` equals the sum of the
digits of `k` plus the sum of the digits of `n - k` minus the sum of digits of `n`, all base `p`.

If `n > 0` then `m` is not divisible by `n` iff it is between `n * k` and `n * (k + 1)`
for some `k`.

name: Int.exists_lt_and_lt_iff_not_dvd
docString:
If `n > 0` then `m` is not divisible by `n` iff it is between `n * k` and `n * (k + 1)`
for some `k`.

`n` is not divisible by `a` iff it is between `a * k` and `a * (k + 1)` for some `k`.

name: Nat.not_dvd_iff_between_consec_multiples
docString: `n` is not divisible by `a` iff it is between `a * k` and `a * (k + 1)` for some `k`.

A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString:
A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

If `n` is a nonzero natural number and `p ≠ 1`, then there are natural numbers `e`
and `n'` such that `n'` is not divisible by `p` and `n = p^e * n'`.

name: Nat.exists_eq_pow_mul_and_not_dvd
docString:
If `n` is a nonzero natural number and `p ≠ 1`, then there are natural numbers `e`
and `n'` such that `n'` is not divisible by `p` and `n = p^e * n'`.
